comments.author: jab_creations@yahoo.com
comments.raw_text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.2; WOW64; rv:2.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0.1
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.2; WOW64; rv:2.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0.1

The benchmark tests how quickly a browser can give focus to each anchor on the color pallet, when focus is given an event listener is supposed to be triggered.

Firefox 4 now fails to either trigger the event listeners or perhaps even give focus to the anchors.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run the benchmark.

Actual Results:  
Either no anchors are given focus or if they are their respective focus event listeners are not triggered.

Expected Results:  
Each anchor on the color pallet is to be given focus and then it's respective event listener triggered.

The benchmark works best in Firefox 3.6 all the way back to Mozilla Suite 1.6 though not 1.5. You can emulate the benchmark by going directly to the editor, enabling advanced controls, enabling the keypress event and then simply holding down the tab key.

comments.author: jab_creations@yahoo.com
comments.text:
I've added a limit HTTP query that allows you to specify how many anchors should be executed in the loop. If it is absent it will automatically execute all the anchors in the color pallet. I've tested and verified that both the normal benchmark and the limited benchmark work respectively in Firefox 3.6 after implementing these changes.

NOTE that this link is DIRECT and will automatically execute the benchmark. This is what I can provide now until I'm able to implement a more user-friendly second button on the benchmark prompt.

http://www.jabcreations.com/web/benchmark/?prompt=themes-editor&benchmark=1&limit=8

comments.creator: jab_creations@yahoo.com
comments.raw_text:
Yes, the benchmark loops through the anchors (now specified or not from the HTTP limit query) and at the end tells you how long it took for the browser to execute the benchmark.

The benchmark and site editor functions are in an ondemand JavaScript file which is only requested when the editor is opened and is therefore not part of index.js; it can be found at this URL...
http://www.jabcreations.com/scripts/site-editor.js

If that does not help enough I'll be happy to create a minimal test case.

comments.raw_text:
By the way if you're trying to see what is supposed to happen do one of the following...

A.) Run the benchmark in Firefox 3.6 or older (to as far back as Mozilla Suite 1.6).

B.) Disable CSS3 (site options), go to the editor, switch to the advanced controls, enable the keypress event and manually hold down the tab key (or press it, let go and repeat subjective to the browser being used).

comments.author: bugs@pettay.fi

comments.text:
Pass means the background-color has VISUALLY changed during the benchmark for EACH and EVERY anchor.

Fail means the background-color has NOT visually changed during the benchmark for EACH and EVERY anchor.

Run the benchmark in Opera 11.1, it only takes 2.3 seconds for Opera to blow through the benchmark while passing it. The failing browsers do not actually giving focus to the anchors (best guess) and therefore failing to trigger the event listeners.

comments.author: bugs@pettay.fi
comments.creator: bugs@pettay.fi
comments.raw_text:
So, browsers try to optimize out extra layout flushes / painting.
If you tab through the test, that happens asynchronously and
layout may be flushed and page repainted between keypresses.
But if you use the benchmark button, that runs the test inside while loop and
nothing forces a browser to repaint for each style change.
comments.text:
So, browsers try to optimize out extra layout flushes / painting.
If you tab through the test, that happens asynchronously and
layout may be flushed and page repainted between keypresses.
But if you use the benchmark button, that runs the test inside while loop and
nothing forces a browser to repaint for each style change.

comments.creator: jab_creations@yahoo.com
comments.raw_text:
So it seems that Firefox will refuse to flush/paint the layout during loops?

I could create another test case to eliminate whatever you suspect is the subjective factor. In example if you think it's the event listeners I could put a loop to have the background-color change from an array of values instead or instead of a loop I could simply copy and paste over and over the background-colors to statically change the background-color.

Let me know how you want to approach this please.

bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.creator: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.raw_text:
> So it seems that Firefox will refuse to flush/paint the layout during loops?

All versions of Firefox refuse to paint while JS is running.  As far as redoing layout, we only do it while JS is running if it explicitly asks for a relayout.
comments.text:
> So it seems that Firefox will refuse to flush/paint the layout during loops?

All versions of Firefox refuse to paint while JS is running.  As far as redoing layout, we only do it while JS is running if it explicitly asks for a relayout.

comments.creator: jab_creations@yahoo.com
comments.text:
Boris, Firefox 3.6 and older run the benchmark fine so at some point in Firefox 4's development something changed.

When you say "layout" I think in terms of height and width, not background-color unless we're talking any changes to the DOM styling at all?

What defines something asking as explicit versus not explicit?
comments.raw_text:
Boris, Firefox 3.6 and older run the benchmark fine so at some point in Firefox 4's development something changed.

comments.author: jab_creations@yahoo.com
bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.creator: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.text:
> Boris, Firefox 3.6 and older run the benchmark fine 

I see identical behavior in Firefox 3.6 and Firefox 4 on the attached testcase, except Firefox 4 is much faster.

> When you say "layout" I think in terms of height and width, not
> background-color unless we're talking any changes to the DOM styling at all?

There are three phases to changes: updating style, updating layout, and painting.  When I said "layout" in comment 17 I meant both of the first two phases; you can actually trigger a style update without triggering a layout update (but asking for layout information will flush out both pending style and pending layout).
comments.raw_text:
> Boris, Firefox 3.6 and older run the benchmark fine 

I see identical behavior in Firefox 3.6 and Firefox 4 on the attached testcase, except Firefox 4 is much faster.

> When you say "layout" I think in terms of height and width, not
> background-color unless we're talking any changes to the DOM styling at all?

There are three phases to changes: updating style, updating layout, and painting.  When I said "layout" in comment 17 I meant both of the first two phases; you can actually trigger a style update without triggering a layout update (but asking for layout information will flush out both pending style and pending layout).

comments.raw_text: I keep different versions of Firefox with their own respective profiles, Firefox 2.0 with a Firefox 2.0 exclusive profile, 3.0, 3.5, 3.6, 4.0, etc and I never open one profile with a different version of Firefox. Mozilla Suite runs the website version of the benchmark fine and I just tested 2.0.14/Firefox 3.5 equivalent and it worked fine. I don't compile any software for any reason though I can only imagine that you both do, that may be the reason why we're seeing differences with the same software and I presume you've both tried using new profiles on top of that?
